#Text=Penrith
#Text=Penrith is a small market town in Cumbria , to the north-east of the Lake District .
#Text=By train
#Text=Penrith is located on the West Coast Mainline rail link .
#Text=There are direct connections to London ( 3 h ) , Edinburgh ( 1 1/2 h ) and Glasgow ( 2h ) .
#Text=By bus
#Text=There are direct bus services from Penrith to London and Scotland , operated by National Express .
#Text=There are local buses from Cockermouth via Keswick and Threlkeld in the northern Lake District every hour or two .
#Text=By car
#Text=Penrith is Situated on the M6 ( junction 40 ) towards Birmingham , A66 from Workington to Grangetown and on the A6 from Luton to Carlisle .
#Text=Get around
#Text=The town can easily be explored on foot .
#Text=See
#Text=The town 's appeal to visitors is somewhat limited to the many fine pubs , the supermarkets and the railway station .
#Text=Penrith does however have some hidden historic gems , most imposingly , Penrith Castle .
#Text=Penrith Castle .

#Text=Building of the castle ' began in 1399 , when William Strickland ( later Bishop of Carlisle and Archbishop of Canterbury ) added a stone wall to an earlier pele tower , primarily as a defence against the then frequent raids from the Scottish borders .
#Text=The castle was improved over the next 70 years , becoming a royal fortress for Richard , Duke of Gloucester before he became King Richard III in 1483 .
#Text=The ruins that can be seen today date from about that time .
#Text=The striking sandstone remains are situated in Castle Park , opposite Penrith railway station .
#Text=free .
#Text=St. Andrew 's Church .
#Text=church often open during the day .
#Text=The churchyard in the town contains the ' Giant 's Thumb ' , a Norse cross dating from 920 AD erected as a memorial to his father by Owen Caesarius , King of Cumbria from 920 to 937 AD .
#Text=There is a tradition that the ' Giant 's Grave ' is the grave of Owen himself .
#Text=The four hogback stones surrounding the grave are said to represent wild boar he killed in nearby Inglewood Forest .
#Text=The two Norse crosses are some 11 feet high .
#Text=The tower dates from 1397 , but the church was built in 1722 and has an interesting interior .
#Text=The church cafe is open Mon - Fri 9:30AM - 2:00PM .
#Text=Penrith and Eden Museum .
#Text=Open all year : Mon - Sat 10am-5pm and on Sun , April to October , 11am-4pm. .
#Text=In Robinson 's School in Middlegate .
#Text=The school closed in 1971 after a long history dating back to 1670 and is now a combined Tourist information centre and museum .
#Text=free .
#Text=Brougham Castle , Moor Lane , CA10 2AA , ☏ +441768862488 .
#Text=adults £4.00 , children £2.40 , concessions £3.60 .
#Text=Acorn Bank , Temple Sowerby , CA10 1SP ( 8 miles east of Penrith ) , ☏ +441768361893 , ✉ acornbank@nationaltrust.org.uk .
#Text=Buy
#Text=James & John Graham Grocers , 6 - 7 Market Square , CA11 7BS .
#Text=Independent grocer established in 1793 , with an excellent selection of cheeses and home baking .
#Text=There are three Supermarkets near the station - Morrisons and Booths in Brunswick Road and Aldi in Ullswater Road .
#Text=Sainsbury 's is on the opposite side of the town centre and the Penrith Co-op is in Burrowgate .
#Text=Eat
#Text=Agricultural Hotel .
#Text=The Castlegate , CA11 7JE .
#Text=Bar meals and Jennings real ales in this hotel near the station .
#Text=Sleep
#Text=The George .
#Text=Is in the town centre
#Text=The North Lakes Hotel and Spa .
#Text=Is a four star hotel on the edge of the town
#Text=Go next
#Text=Just outside the town is Brougham Castle , which is much better preserved than Penrith Castle which is situated alongside the earth-works of a Roman Fort .
#Text=The site was later taken by the Norman family of Vieuxpont to build their castle , the ruins the stone keep , and service buildings can still be seen .
#Text=Ullswater , the Eden Valley and the Rheged Centre are all very nearby .
#Text=The neighbouring towns are Keswick to the west , Appleby in Westmorland to the south east , and the city of Carlisle to the north .
